NewsLine.NewsLineText: WORLD-HIGHLIGHTS 1000 GMT:Reuters World News Highlights 1000 GMT Sept 23

body.p: BERLIN - German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder faces the task of reforming Europe's largest economy with a sharply reduced majority after he and his Greens coalition partners narrowly won Sunday's general election.

"We have difficult times ahead," a visibly merry Schroeder called to his jubilant Social Democrat (SPD) supporters after voters cut his majority over the combined opposition parties to nine from 21 at the last election.
RAMALLAH, West Bank - Israeli troops pressed on with their siege of Yasser Arafat's West Bank headquarters after halting demolition of his presidential complex following U.S. criticism.
Troops stood guard in the levelled compound where only one main building remains standing, sheltering the Palestinian president and up to 250 others.

BOUAKE, Ivory Coast - French troops rumbled north to evacuate Westerners trapped by fighting in Ivory Coast as skirmishes flared on the outskirts of a city where dozens of American children are hiding.

Rebel soldiers said they had beaten off a heavy attack on the city of Bouake by loyalist troops sent to crush an uprising that has plunged the West African country into its worst crisis since independence from France in 1960.
BAGHDAD - Iraq denounced as "wicked" U.S. attempts at the United Nations to adopt a tough resolution on Iraq's disarmament, saying Washington was seeking U.N. cover for any military action.
"These American attempts to issue a new (U.N.) resolution have bad intentions and wicked aims," said al-Thawra newspaper, mouthpiece of the ruling Baath Party.
SRINAGAR, India - Violence flared ahead of the second round of Indian Kashmir's state elections that Islamic militants have vowed to sabotage, as security forces gunned down four rebels, police said.
"The four separatists were killed on Monday in the gun battle which has been going on since last night and is still happening," a police official told Reuters.
MERIDA, Mexico - Hurricane Isidore ploughed across Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, forcing thousands from their homes as it flooded streets, toppled trees and power lines and shut down offshore oil rigs.

About 70,000 people in low-lying fishing villages on the peninsula were evacuated to shelters after torrential rains flooded homes and roads, and winds of more than 120 mph (195 kph) ripped off roofs and uprooted trees.

MADRID - Spain denied Moroccan claims that a Spanish military helicopter had landed on a disputed Mediterranean islet and said it regretted Rabat's cancellation of talks planned for Monday to smooth troubled relations.
The tiny uninhabited island some 200 metres (yards) off the Moroccan coast was the source of a conflict in July when the Spanish military kicked off Moroccan troops at gunpoint.
JAKARTA - A grenade exploded in a car outside a U.S. embassy warehouse in the centre of Indonesia's capital Jakarta in a botched attack that killed one of the vehicle's occupants, police said.

The incident came at a time of heightened security at U.S. embassies worldwide following what Washington called credible terrorist threats marking the anniversary of the September 11, 2001, attacks on New York and Washington.

PUSAN, South Korea - North Korean athletes and officials arrived in South Korea's second city of Pusan to compete in the Asian Games, the latest in a unprecedented flurry of contacts between the rival states.

In the first part of the largest delegation North Korea has sent to the South, 159 athletes and team staff, as well as 14 doctors and journalists, arrived on a chartered flight in Pusan, the venue of the September 29-October 14 games.
